sections.index_intro: Headlines, letters, rants and rumours from the CPC universe.

pages.title: Scene News Desk
pages.intro: Fresh disks, fresh demos, fresh cheek.
paragraphs: Coders keep squeezing the CPC with sharper rasters and cleaner scrolling text.
Small teams still ship clever ideas because they plan first and panic later.

box.label: DID YOU KNOW?
box.text: Mode 2 text pages still look brilliant on a green screen.

pages.title: Letters Bag
pages.intro: Real post, real opinions, real tea stains.
paragraphs: Readers ask about sticky keys, floppy belts and where to begin with assembler.
Best advice this week: write tiny routines and test on every change.
bullets: Most honest letter: I broke it by rushing.

box.label: MAIL ROOM
box.text: If your SPACE bar sticks, clean gently and keep cola away.

pages.title: Rant Column
paragraphs: Saying old machines are pointless misses the point of learning under constraints.
The CPC teaches structure, discipline and timing better than many modern toys.

box.label: RANT
box.text: If your game only works with luck, it is not finished.

pages.title: Cover Tape Dream
pages.intro: A fantasy issue stuffed with goodies.
paragraphs: Imagine one tape with a game, an art tool and a utility that saves your week.
Budget labels proved tiny teams can produce huge joy with tiny memory.

box.label: NEXT MONTH
box.text: Write in if you want a type-in game special.

pages.title: Interview Desk
pages.intro: Firmware talk with a practical wizard.
paragraphs: The pro answer stayed the same: use firmware vectors and avoid brittle hardcoded addresses.
Compatibility work is not boring; it keeps software alive for decades.

box.label: PRO QUOTE
box.text: Fast code is nice, portable code survives.

pages.title: Did You Know?
pages.intro: Little facts for big bragging rights.
paragraphs: The CPC keyboard is matrix scanned and tightly linked with the machine sound hardware.
The mixed-chip design is quirky, but that quirk is where the tricks live.

box.label: TRIVIA
box.text: Many classic effects come from timing more than raw speed.

pages.title: Next Month Board
pages.intro: Plans are bold, deadlines are louder.
paragraphs: We are prepping a joystick stress test and another beginner assembly workshop.
Reader projects will get a full spotlight if they include notes and source.

box.label: TRY THIS
box.text: Send one bug story and one fix that worked.

pages.title: Classifieds
paragraphs: The message board is full of disk boxes, spare cables and heroic claims about perfect joysticks.
Every advert is short, spicy and probably typed in a hurry.

box.label: NOTICE
box.text: No links, no hype, just plain text and trust.

pages.title: Feature Long Read
paragraphs: Magazine culture mixed humour, coding and reader experiments in one loud monthly ritual.
Kids learned by typing, testing, failing and reading the letters page again.

box.label: DID YOU KNOW?
box.text: Many coders started from one listing in a magazine.

pages.title: Editorial Signoff
pages.intro: Keep it curious and keep it kind.
paragraphs: When you share tools and notes, everyone improves and the scene gets stronger.
If your experiment fails, write what failed and someone else will finish it.

box.label: EDITOR NOTE
box.text: Smart, cheeky and generous is the AMSHOLE way.

sections.name: CPC Hardware & History
sections.index_intro: Machines, monitors, drives and decades of practical design.

pages.title: Model Family
paragraphs: The 464 brought tape convenience, the 664 introduced built-in disk, and the 6128 pushed memory further.
All three shared a tidy out-of-box setup that families could actually manage.

box.label: HISTORY
box.text: Bundled monitor plus power design reduced setup chaos.

pages.title: Monitor Choices
pages.intro: Green screen discipline or full colour punch.
paragraphs: The green monitor made text razor sharp and coding sessions easy on tired eyes.
Colour display gave games their full personality with bright pen combinations.

box.label: TIP
box.text: Test both text and sprites before choosing your setup.

pages.title: Disk and AMSDOS
paragraphs: AMSDOS added disk commands that made development loops shorter and less painful.
Directory structures and headers reward careful organisation and consistent naming.

box.label: DID YOU KNOW?
box.text: Firmware variables keep drive and user state ready for tools.

pages.title: Plus Range
paragraphs: The Plus line added hardware features that opened new visual options for developers.
Compatibility with earlier software remained a practical concern for most projects.

box.label: CALL OUT
box.text: Short market life, long conversation.

pages.title: M4 Expansion Board
paragraphs: M4 command exchange uses a dataport and an acknowledge port for host communication.
File, network and socket commands are provided through a ROM-level response buffer.

box.label: TECH NOTE
box.text: Read the response pointer, do not hardcode it.

pages.title: Expansion Ecosystem
pages.intro: ROM boards, printers, memory and odd delights.
paragraphs: The expansion scene let users build personal setups from utility-heavy to game-heavy.
A thoughtful ROM collection turned a home machine into a compact productivity station.

box.label: SCENE NOTE
box.text: Half lab bench, half toy chest.

pages.title: Scene Timeline
pages.intro: From launch splash to modern preservation.
paragraphs: The original boom years built a mountain of software and magazines.
Later scene work and archives kept games, docs and source alive.

box.label: REMEMBER
box.text: Backups and notes are cultural preservation.

pages.title: Collector Checks
paragraphs: Check keyboard feel, drive behaviour, cable health and display output before paying.
A complete working unit often beats a rare but broken machine.

box.label: BUY SMART
box.text: Patience saves money and repair time.

pages.title: Service Basics
paragraphs: Gentle cleaning and proper storage do more than aggressive repair attempts.
Label repairs and track dates so future troubleshooting is faster.

box.label: WORKSHOP
box.text: Slow careful work beats rushed heroics.

pages.title: Legacy and Lessons
paragraphs: The CPC story shows that sensible engineering and friendly design can build lasting communities.
Constraint-based learning remains useful for modern coding education.

box.label: FINAL WORD
box.text: History is useful when it informs better practice.

sections.name: Games Zone
sections.index_intro: Arcade thrills, design notes and bragging rights.

pages.title: Arcade Blasters
paragraphs: Great arcade games reward quick reads and tighter input than flashy intros.
Mode and palette choices should improve visibility, not just spectacle.

box.label: GAME DESIGN
box.text: One more go is the true success metric.

pages.title: Adventure Corner
paragraphs: Text adventures build logic habits and reward careful observation.
Helpful hints beat unfair dead ends when designing your own game.

box.label: TRY THIS
box.text: Design one puzzle with two valid solutions.

pages.title: Platform Lab
paragraphs: Animation and collision tuning matter more than huge sprite counts.
Difficulty curves should teach first and challenge second.

box.label: DID YOU KNOW?
box.text: Players forgive hard levels, not unfair rules.

pages.title: Strategy Shelf
paragraphs: Turn-based design suits constrained hardware and gives room for deeper systems.
Good feedback loops make complex rules feel understandable.

box.label: NOTE
box.text: Teach your systems in the first two turns.

pages.title: Public Domain Picks
paragraphs: Public domain collections mixed rough experiments with genuine hidden gems.
Curation and reader recommendations made discovery faster.

box.label: SCENE RULE
box.text: Share responsibly and preserve metadata.

pages.title: Two Player Chaos
paragraphs: Balanced controls and clear scoring keep multiplayer sessions fun.
Alternating turns still works brilliantly when rounds are short.

box.label: HOUSE RULE
box.text: Winner keeps score, loser makes tea.

pages.title: Hidden Gems
paragraphs: Some low-price releases had inventive mechanics and memorable art direction.
Trying odd genres often reveals your next favourite.

box.label: GEM HUNT
box.text: Underhyped titles often take bigger risks.

pages.title: Make a Game
paragraphs: Start with one mechanic, one screen and one clear goal.
Prototype controls first, then layer visuals and sound.

box.label: PROJECT
box.text: Finished and simple beats endless and broken.

pages.title: Hiscore Club
paragraphs: Record game, score, date and mode so runs can be compared fairly.
Friendly taunts are welcome; fake scores are not.

box.label: LEAGUE NOTE
box.text: Honest records build better competition.

pages.title: Design Retrospective
paragraphs: Strong games communicate rules instantly and reward learning patterns over luck.
Tight constraints often produced very readable design decisions.

box.label: WRAP UP
box.text: Good design remains good long after hardware shifts.

sections.name: CPC Internals Deep Dive
sections.index_intro: Registers, timing and hardware behaviour in plain language.

pages.title: Z80 Memory Map
paragraphs: The Z80 sees address space from 0000h to FFFFh, with ROM and RAM visibility controlled by hardware state.
Treat memory layout as a map before coding, especially when mixing firmware and custom routines.

box.label: TABLE
box.text: Sketch your active map per routine to avoid collisions.

pages.title: ROM and RAM Banking
pages.intro: Visibility rules make or break tools.
paragraphs: Banked memory on expanded models allows large buffers and data banks beyond the base visible window.
Safe code keeps stack and critical variables in stable regions during bank switches.

box.label: RULE
box.text: Document bank usage, then enforce it.

pages.title: Gate Array Behaviour
paragraphs: The Gate Array handles palette and display mode control and interacts with timing-sensitive effects.
Cycle-accurate writes are essential when producing stable raster colour changes.

box.label: LAB NOTE
box.text: One missed cycle can shift an entire bar.

pages.title: CRTC Registers and Timing
paragraphs: CRTC registers control horizontal and vertical totals, displayed regions and start addresses.
Different CRTC variants can differ in edge behaviour, so testing across hardware matters.

box.label: DID YOU KNOW?
box.text: Minor register shifts can create major visual changes.

pages.title: Interrupt Rhythm
paragraphs: The CPC interrupt flow supports regular tasks such as music stepping and split timing checks.
Keep handlers short and move heavy logic to the main loop using flags.

box.label: PRACTICE
box.text: Measure jitter before rewriting code paths.

pages.title: Raster Tricks
paragraphs: Raster bars and split screens rely on precise timing of register and palette updates.
Debugging with border colour markers helps locate drift quickly.

box.label: TIP
box.text: Lock one effect before adding the next.

pages.title: AY-3-8912 Sound Internals
paragraphs: The AY chip exposes tone periods, mixer controls, noise and envelopes for expressive audio.
Smart channel allocation keeps effects clear without destroying your melody line.

box.label: AUDIO TABLE
box.text: Track register writes to debug stuck notes.

pages.title: Keyboard Matrix
paragraphs: Keyboard input is matrix scanned, so robust polling and debounce logic matter.
Control systems should support held keys and diagonals without accidental repeats.

box.label: INPUT NOTE
box.text: Fast games live or die on clean controls.

pages.title: Firmware Vectors
paragraphs: Firmware vector calls abstract lower-level implementation details and improve portability.
When extending with hardware like M4, keep interfaces explicit and read system pointers dynamically.

box.label: REFERENCE
box.text: Compatibility is part of technical quality.

pages.title: Internals Workbench
paragraphs: Build tiny repeatable tests for memory mapping, timing and sound behaviour.
Record register values, machine variant and observed output in a simple table.

box.label: WORK METHOD
box.text: Good notes turn hacks into knowledge.

sections.name: Tips and Tricks
sections.index_intro: Sharper workflow, fewer headaches, better results.

pages.title: Disk Speed Habits
paragraphs: Group related assets and source files so your iteration loop stays fast.
A clean directory plan is a performance tool, not just housekeeping.

box.label: TIP
box.text: Two backup copies beat one heroic apology.

pages.title: BASIC Speed-ups
paragraphs: Move repeated calculations outside loops and reduce unnecessary redraws.
Optimise hotspots you measured, not the entire listing at random.

box.label: RULE
box.text: Profile first, optimise second.

pages.title: Memory Savers
paragraphs: Shared buffers and compact data formats free space for gameplay and polish.
Bit packing for flags can remove surprising amounts of overhead.

box.label: DID YOU KNOW?
box.text: Simple compression can rescue a near-finished build.

pages.title: Debugging Routine
paragraphs: Shrink bugs into tiny reproducible cases, then test one change at a time.
Write assumptions down; most hard bugs are hidden assumptions.

box.label: WORKFLOW
box.text: Slow is smooth, smooth is fast.

pages.title: Sprite Practice
paragraphs: Masking and clipping discipline keeps rendering clean and efficient.
Pre-shifted assets can trade memory for valuable CPU time.

box.label: ART TIP
box.text: Silhouette clarity wins at game speed.

pages.title: Sound Polish
paragraphs: Use short cues for action feedback and reserve melody space for identity.
Dynamic channel priority prevents effects from swallowing important tones.

box.label: AUDIO NOTE
box.text: If every sound is loud, none are special.

pages.title: Input Shortcuts
paragraphs: Map common editor actions to nearby keys and display hints on-screen.
Offer redefine controls to support different users and setups.

box.label: UX
box.text: Predictable controls reduce support problems.

pages.title: Safe Maintenance
pages.intro: Protect the machine while fixing it.
paragraphs: Power down fully before opening hardware and avoid force on old plastics.
Clean contacts gently and store media away from dust and magnets.

box.label: SAFETY
box.text: Rushing repairs often creates new faults.

pages.title: Cheat Ethics
paragraphs: Cheats can be useful for exploration and testing, especially while learning level flow.
Competition scores should stay honest so leaderboards mean something.

box.label: CODE OF PLAY
box.text: Honest wins feel better and last longer.

pages.title: Project Checklist
pages.intro: A tiny list that prevents giant pain.
paragraphs: Define scope, plan milestones and test each milestone before adding new features.
Release early and gather feedback while changes are still cheap.

box.label: WRAP
box.text: Completion is a skill you can practise.

sections.name: Learn to Code
sections.index_intro: Beginner friendly coding lessons with playful examples.

pages.title: Variables
paragraphs: Use clear names for score, lives and level so logic reads like plain speech.
Set default values at startup to avoid mysterious behaviour later.

box.label: BEGINNER TIP
box.text: Good names are free documentation.

pages.title: Loops
paragraphs: FOR loops are great for counted tasks; condition loops are great for ongoing states.
Always update state inside loops so exit conditions can actually be reached.

box.label: TRY THIS
box.text: Write a loop that prints a tiny progress bar.

pages.title: If and Then
paragraphs: Conditional logic drives collisions, scoring and menu flow.
Read each condition aloud; if it sounds confusing, simplify it.

box.label: CHECK
box.text: Test min, max and weird inputs.

pages.title: Arrays and Data
pages.intro: Structured storage for levels and stats.
paragraphs: Arrays store repeated values efficiently and keep related data grouped.
Data tables are ideal for maps, enemy waves and score thresholds.

box.label: DATA BOX
box.text: Table-driven design keeps code tidy.

pages.title: Graphics Basics
pages.intro: Choose the right mode for the job.
paragraphs: Mode choices affect colour count, detail and readability.
Redraw only changed areas when possible to reduce flicker and cost.

box.label: ART START
box.text: Start readable, then add flair.

pages.title: Sound Basics
paragraphs: Simple motifs and short effects make games feel alive and responsive.
Match tempo to gameplay pace and keep cue meanings consistent.

box.label: LISTEN
box.text: If a cue confuses players, redesign it.

pages.title: Procedures
paragraphs: Modular code lets you test features independently and reuse logic safely.
Name routines after actions so call sites read naturally.

box.label: STRUCTURE
box.text: Small routines make big projects manageable.

pages.title: Assembler Starter
paragraphs: Begin with tiny routines and call them from BASIC while measuring real benefit.
Comment register usage so integration bugs are easier to spot.

box.label: MACHINE CODE
box.text: Hybrid BASIC plus ASM can be ideal.

pages.title: Mini Project
paragraphs: Implement movement, hazards, score and lives before adding polish.
Ship a complete tiny game, then iterate from feedback.

box.label: GOAL
box.text: Completion creates confidence.

pages.title: Learning Plan
paragraphs: Split learning into focused sessions for logic, graphics, sound and cleanup.
Review old code every week and refactor one small area.

box.label: MOTTO
box.text: Steady practice beats heroic bursts.

sections.name: Art, Graphics and Sound
sections.index_intro: Visual style, music craft and presentation polish.

pages.title: Mode 0 Pixel Art
paragraphs: Chunky pixels reward clear silhouettes and careful colour contrast.
Strong shape language reads better than tiny detail clutter.

box.label: ART RULE
box.text: Readable beats ornate every time.

pages.title: Palette Tricks
paragraphs: Palette swaps can signal danger, nighttime or power states cheaply.
Consistent colour semantics help players read status quickly.

box.label: TIP
box.text: Border colour can reinforce scene mood.

pages.title: Charset Magic
paragraphs: Custom character sets are memory-efficient for UI and map-like displays.
Consistent tile rules simplify editing and bug fixing.

box.label: UI BOX
box.text: A good font is part of game feel.

pages.title: Scroller Style
paragraphs: Scrollers work best with short sharp lines and deliberate pacing.
Synchronising text rhythm with music accents adds energy.

box.label: SCENE STYLE
box.text: A tiny joke can carry a long scroller.

pages.title: AY Music Basics
paragraphs: Treat channels as roles: lead, support and pulse or bass depending on tempo.
Arpeggios and envelope motion can imply richness with minimal cost.

box.label: MUSIC
box.text: Clarity beats dense note spam.

pages.title: Drum Illusions
paragraphs: Noise bursts and fast pitch movement can create convincing rhythm accents.
Small timing offsets prevent patterns from feeling robotic.

box.label: RHYTHM LAB
box.text: Variation creates life.

pages.title: Demo Layout
paragraphs: Open with clarity, escalate with contrast and finish with a memorable signature.
Transitions should be intentional and quick to keep momentum.

box.label: STAGING
box.text: Order matters as much as effects.

pages.title: Text FX
paragraphs: Colour headers and separators guide readers through dense information.
Short pull quotes and callout boxes maintain pace.

box.label: DID YOU KNOW?
box.text: Good layout reduces support questions.

pages.title: Scene Etiquette
paragraphs: Always credit coders, artists and musicians clearly in releases and docs.
Constructive critique helps everyone improve without killing morale.

box.label: CODE OF SCENE
box.text: Skill and respect can coexist.

pages.title: Portfolio Page
paragraphs: Present art and music snippets with short notes describing tools and constraints.
A clean archive helps future collaborators understand your workflow.

box.label: CAREER TIP
box.text: Process notes are as valuable as output.

sections.name: Fun Stuff
sections.index_intro: Quizzes, jokes, fake adverts and letters.

pages.title: Quiz Round One
pages.intro: Six quick questions for hardware nerds.
paragraphs: Test your memory on models, chips and display modes.
No calculators, no peeking, no sibling hint network.

box.label: QUIZ
box.text: Answers appear later in this section.

pages.title: Quiz Round Two
paragraphs: This round covers ports, interrupts and practical coding habits.
Award yourself extra points for explaining why, not just what.

box.label: BONUS
box.text: Write one answer in plain language for a friend.

pages.title: Quiz Answers
paragraphs: If you got most answers right, congratulations: you are officially deep in CPC lore.
If not, that is fine; curiosity beats scoreboards.

box.label: RESULTS
box.text: Knowledge grows fastest when shared.

pages.title: Joke Zone
paragraphs: Why did the coder fear line ten? Because line ten had no comment and bad intent.
What is the official fuel of debugging? Tea and stubbornness.

box.label: JOKE POLICY
box.text: If someone snorts tea, success.

pages.title: Letters Page
paragraphs: Questions this month include game balance, coding confidence and best beginner projects.
Most useful answer: start tiny, finish tiny, then grow.

box.label: LETTERS
box.text: Handwritten notes always get extra style points.

pages.title: Fake Ad Break
paragraphs: Presenting the Turbo Grip Handle, now with almost trustworthy diagonals.
Also available: the Anti-Waiting Chair for dramatic tape loads.

box.label: AD COPY
box.text: Educational claims are entirely theatrical.

pages.title: 8-Bit Horoscope
paragraphs: Keyboard sign: you will find a bug and name it politely.
Disk sign: you will finally make that backup you keep postponing.

box.label: COSMIC TIP
box.text: Hydrate before debugging.

pages.title: Top Ten Team Names
paragraphs: This month includes Raster Rascals, ROM Raiders and The Syntax Survivors.
Vote with your keyboard and an unreasonable level of enthusiasm.

box.label: VOTE
box.text: Shouting at the monitor is optional but encouraged.

pages.title: Next Issue Tease
paragraphs: Expect a giant internals chart, classroom projects and another big reader challenge.
Best submissions get spotlight space and eternal bragging rights.

box.label: TEASER
box.text: Bring your wildest but testable ideas.

pages.title: Fun Signoff
paragraphs: Fun pages are silly on purpose, but the community spirit behind them is serious.
Keep sending jokes, quizzes and letters for the next run.

box.label: BYE FOR NOW
box.text: See you next issue, same loud colours.

sections.name: Parents and Teachers
sections.index_intro: How the CPC supports learning at home and school.

pages.title: Why It Works
paragraphs: Children can see direct cause and effect between code and result very quickly.
Constraint-rich environments build planning, patience and debugging habits.

box.label: EDU NOTE
box.text: Making beats consuming for long-term skill.

pages.title: Classroom Setup
paragraphs: One learner types while another reviews, then they swap every short interval.
Visible goals and short demos keep sessions focused and energetic.

box.label: PRACTICE
box.text: Frequent swaps improve attention.

pages.title: Budgeting
paragraphs: Allocate funds for tested hardware, spare media and simple maintenance items.
A shared lab setup often lowers cost per student significantly.

box.label: FINANCE TIP
box.text: Predictable upkeep beats emergency repairs.

pages.title: Safe Habits
pages.intro: Respect the kit and the room.
paragraphs: No drinks near machines, clean shutdowns and labelled disks reduce accidents.
Shared responsibility routines also teach teamwork and care.

box.label: CLASS RULE
box.text: Carefulness is part of computing literacy.

pages.title: Project Ideas
paragraphs: Math quizzes, history timelines and science simulations all fit the CPC classroom model.
Small scope with clear deadlines keeps delivery realistic.

box.label: TEACHER TOOL
box.text: Coding projects can support many subjects.

pages.title: Coding Clubs
paragraphs: A short weekly club sustains momentum and gives time for reflection between meetings.
Role rotation helps each learner experience design, coding and testing.

box.label: CLUB NOTE
box.text: Consistency creates confident learners.

pages.title: Game Evaluation
paragraphs: Ask learners to evaluate clarity, fairness and feedback in the games they play.
Structured critique improves both analysis and future project quality.

box.label: ASSESSMENT
box.text: Explain your judgement with evidence.

pages.title: History Links
paragraphs: The CPC era shows how distribution, constraints and community shaped software practice.
Students can compare older workflows with modern tools to understand fundamentals.

box.label: HISTORY
box.text: Past constraints explain many modern patterns.

pages.title: Buying Checklist
paragraphs: Verify boot behaviour, keyboard response, display output and drive movement.
Ask for repair history and storage conditions when possible.

box.label: CHECKLIST
box.text: Document serials and service notes.

pages.title: Parents Signoff
paragraphs: Encourage experimentation while setting clear routines for safety and documentation.
Celebrate persistence and clear thinking, not just final polish.

box.label: FINAL NOTE
box.text: Learning to debug is learning to think.

help.title: Help, About and Credits
paragraphs: Use number keys on menu and section index frames to jump by page number.
0 always returns to the main index page, and # goes to this help page where routing tables apply.
Article frames are designed for simple reading with safe Telstar markup and CRLF line endings.
credits: AMSHOLE is a fictional CPC fan magazine service.
Technical notes are remixed from local repository documents including firmware and M4 developer material.
Public reference knowledge from classic CPC documentation, community summaries and encyclopedia-style sources.
No external links are shown in-frame to keep pages clean and period-flavoured.
